G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 28A.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jennifer Smith, in accordance with G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 28A, and respectfully moves this Honorable Court to modify the custody and parenting time order regarding the minor child, Emma Smith, issued by this Court on May 15, 2017.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and the established caselaw articulated in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), the best interests of the child is the paramount consideration in all custody and parenting time matters.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and the established caselaw articulated in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), the best interests of the child is the paramount consideration in all custody and parenting time matters.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that under the removal statute, the words “upon cause shown” mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and that the best interests of the children remain the paramount concern. It applies this best-interests standard in resolving both physical custody and removal, rejecting any contrary presumption (such as a presumption for joint physical custody), thereby affirming that in custody and parenting-time related determinations, the child’s best interests control.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”}

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Custody orders may be modified upon material changes in circumstances.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standards for making an initial custody determination (best interests of the child, equal parental rights, and the appropriateness of joint vs. sole custody), but it does not address modification of an existing custody order based on a material change in circumstances. There is no language about the legal standard for modifying custody or about changed circumstances as a prerequisite to modification. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that custody orders may be modified upon material changes in circumstances.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.… It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Courts may consider the child’s preference where appropriate for evaluating best interests.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion thoroughly discusses the best-interests standard, weighing expert testimony, stability, sibling bonds, and competing adoption plans, but it does not mention or analyze the child’s own stated wishes or preference. Hugo is very young and the court never suggests that his preference is a factor, nor does it articulate any general rule about considering a child’s preference in best-interests determinations. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the proposition that courts may consider the child’s preference when appropriate.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … [A] judge may consider a wide range of permissible evidence in determining which placement will serve the child’s best interests.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Significant improvement in a parent’s circumstances can justify a modification.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that a Probate Court may modify a prior custody judgment upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and upholds the judge’s finding that the mother’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence’ constituted such a change. Although the appellate court reverses on the best-interests analysis regarding splitting the twins, it affirms that the mother’s significant rehabilitation was a sufficient material change to justify allowing the modification complaint. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that a significant improvement in a parent’s circumstances can justify modification.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28… enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children… In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’… Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: A strong and continuing bond between a parent and child is relevant to custody determinations.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the removal decision in terms of the children’s ‘best interests’ and emphasizes the harm from reducing the father’s parenting time where the parents share joint physical custody. While it does not use the phrase ‘strong and continuing bond,’ it clearly treats the preservation of frequent and continued contact and the child’s relationships with both parents as a central, relevant factor in the custody/removal analysis, which aligns with the proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Where physical custody is shared and neither parent has a clear majority of custodial responsibility, the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’ … Distant relocation often impedes ‘frequent and continued contact’ with the remaining joint custodian. See G. L. c. 208, § 31.”

Whelan v. Whelan, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 616.raw_text: Whelan v. Whelan, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 616 (2009)
Whelan v. Whelan, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 616.proposition: Therapist Recommendations: Consideration of professional evaluations concerning the child’s needs is critical.
Whelan v. Whelan, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 616.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of child support, calculation of a self‑employed parent’s income, and allocation of health insurance costs. It does not discuss therapist recommendations, professional psychological evaluations, or how such evaluations should factor into decisions about a child’s needs. Because the case never addresses mental health professionals’ input or custody/parenting-time determinations based on such evaluations, it does not support the stated proposition.
Whelan v. Whelan, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 616.relevant_excerpt: On remand, the judge should, on remand, consider whether an increase in support is warranted. It will be appropriate to consider not only the fact and amount of the father’s increased income in determining whether “a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred,” ... but also any increased needs of the mother and of the children as well as the station in life of the respective parties.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: A stable home environment supports a parent’s request for increased custody.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that stability and continuity in a child’s living arrangements and preserving existing satisfactory caregiving arrangements are central to the ‘best interests’ analysis. It explains that maintaining an existing, satisfactory home arrangement is ordinarily in the child’s best interests and that unnecessary disruption of a stable arrangement risks harm. While the case focuses more on continuity with the primary caregiver than on ‘increased custody’ per se, its reasoning clearly treats a stable home environment as a factor supporting custody decisions, which aligns with the proposition in a general sense.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Both parents should be involved in the upbringing of the child unless it is contrary to the child's welfare.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion does not state the proposition in those exact words, but it applies a best-interests-of-the-child standard that explicitly values a child having two involved parents. In affirming primary physical custody to Hunter, the court stresses that, when only one parent can have sole physical custody due to geography, it is in the child’s best interests to be with the parent who "can support the involvement of both parents" rather than the parent who alienates the child from the other. This aligns with the idea that both parents should be involved unless that would be contrary to the child’s welfare.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, "it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent." Moreover, she found that Hunter was entirely supportive of Jill’s relationship with Rose and respects Rose’s role as Jill’s other parent.

Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325.raw_text: Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325 (2010)
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325.proposition: Courts retain considerable discretion in modifying custody arrangements for the child’s best interests.
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reiterates that in Massachusetts custody disputes the overarching principle is the child’s best interests, and that what is in a child’s best interest is left largely to the discretion of the judge, who may consider any pertinent factor. Although the case’s main issue is comity to a foreign custody order rather than modification of an existing domestic order, its discussion of the best‑interests standard underscores that custody determinations are highly discretionary and child‑centered, which is consistent with the proposition about courts’ considerable discretion in altering custody for a child’s best interests.
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of a child is the overarching principle that governs custody disputes in the Commonwealth. … What is in a child’s best interest depends upon the particular needs of the child, and is left largely to the discretion of the judge, who ‘may consider any factor pertinent to those interests.’ … [T]he best interests analysis is a child-centered one that focuses on the specific needs and interests of a child and how these might best be met.”

Comerford v. Comerford, 375 Mass. 569 (1.proposition: Custody and parenting time decisions must promote a child’s welfare.
Comerford v. Comerford, 375 Mass. 569 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a tort case about recovery for negligent infliction of emotional distress and abandonment of the ‘impact’ rule. It does not involve custody, parenting time (visitation), domestic relations, or standards governing child welfare in custody determinations. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that custody and parenting time decisions must promote a child’s welfare.
Comerford v. Comerford, 375 Mass. 569 (1.relevant_excerpt: These appeals require us to reexamine the question whether a person who negligently causes emotional distress which leads to physical injuries may be liable for those injuries even if the injured person neither was threatened with nor sustained any direct physical injury. At the heart of the plaintiffs’ claims is the argument that this court should abandon the so called “impact” rule of Spade v. Lynn & Boston R.R., 168 Mass. 285, 290 (1897), which denies recovery for physical injuries arising solely from negligently caused mental distress.
